head.title: Our Science Priorities Need More Scrutiny

hedline.hl1: Our Science Priorities Need More Scrutiny

block.p: Big science is lobbying hard in Congress for several big ticket items: the superconducting supercollider ($4 billion); the human genome project ($6 billion) and the manned space station ($14.6 billion).

Proponents of these projects argue that there will be great technological spinoffs in the marketplace. But that is true of most scientific innovation, and these projects displace other research efforts. For example, manned space efforts have squeezed budgets for scientific exploration of the planets just when we need to know more about the atmospheres of Venus and Mars to understand the impending greenhouse effect on Earth.

Also, with the human population increasing by 87 million annually, contraceptive research is lagging by at least $100 million a year. Mass extinction of 20 percent to 30 percent of plant and animal species will occur in the next few decades because of habitat destruction. We need several hundred new Ph.D. taxonomists and research chemists to catalogue the several million species that have not been classified or examined for possible useful drugs or genes.
The supercollider can wait, but population growth and species extinction need prompt attention. Big science shouldn't be driven by pork barrel expediency MARK OBERLE, M.D. Seattle, March 12, 1988
The writer is visiting assistant professor of public health, U. of Washington.
